summary: This document is a brochure from Palm Beach County Victim Services & Certified Rape Crisis Center, outlining services, rights, and resources for victims of violent crimes, including sexual assault. It details victim compensation, forensic exams, and advocacy services, and appears to be a general informational resource rather than a case-specific document. This document is a Florida Bureau of Victim Compensation application form (BVC 100). It is a template for victims of crime to apply for financial assistance, detailing eligibility requirements, required documentation, and various types of compensation available (e.g., for medical expenses, lost wages, property loss, relocation). It includes sections for crime information, insurance details, and attorney representation.
keyFacts: The document is a victim services brochure from Palm Beach County, dated May 2015, outlining rights and resources for victims of sexual assault and other violent crimes.
It details Florida statutes regarding victim rights, including the right to confidentiality with a sexual assault counselor and the legal definition of sexual battery (rape).
It describes the forensic exam process for sexual assault victims, including evidence collection and kit processing timelines.
It lists contact information for the Palm Beach County Victim Services & Certified Rape Crisis Center and other state resources like the Florida Council Against Sexual Violence.
The document includes a victim compensation claim form from the Florida Office of the Attorney General, Bureau of Victim Compensation.
The document is a standard Florida victim compensation application form, not a case-specific filing.
It outlines strict eligibility criteria, including mandatory crime reporting to law enforcement within 72 hours (with exceptions) and filing the claim within one year of the crime.
Compensation is described as a 'payment of last resort,' requiring victims to exhaust all other sources (insurance, settlements) and potentially repay the fund if other payments are received later.
The form includes specific programs for victims of sexual battery, domestic violence, and human trafficking, offering relocation assistance.
Acceptable 'Proof of Crime' includes law enforcement reports, charging affidavits, grand jury indictments, or FBI reports, indicating the program relies on official determinations.
